items.title: Wordlist filter feature issues
items.body:
I think there's some optimizations to be made with the new custom wordlist feature.

I upgraded packages wholesale and got a new titlecase.  Out of the box, every time I run my app I get thousands of this message:

    No config file found at C:\Users\user\.titlecase.txt [titlecase:79 create_wordlist_filter]

I can suppress the logging message, but I cannot stop titlecase from looking for a file I know to not be there.  Also, if I DID use this file, it would very inefficiently have to find, open, and read this file upon every titlecase invocation.

So, a couple thoughts:
* The default `titlecase` wordlist_file=None should actually mean there is no wordlist file, rather than for the method to default to a magic filename to check over and over.
* Keep a cache or require the user to just pass a wordlist array from memory, so you don't have to open and read this file repeatedly. If I can just call titlecase with "ignore_words=['FBI', 'CIA', 'NSA']" then we can avoid all the file stuff and it's attendant performance issues and logging noise.
* At a minimum, one way or another I must be able to disable the file loading capability.

items.title: ‘Mc’-prefixed small words are not capitalized within slash-joined compound words
items.body:
Although there are no real surnames that start with `Mc` and continue
with a small word, it feels weird for a string like `mcto/mcby` to be
title-cased into `McTo/Mcby`, and not `McTo/McBy`, even though both
‘to’ and ‘by’ are small words—just because the `small_first_last`
argument is set to `False` in the slash-induced (and, if #63 is
merged, hyphen-induced) recursion.

items.title: Small words are erroneously capitalized within hyphenated compound words
items.body:
When `titlecase()` recurses to process separate words of a hyphenated
compound word, it passes on the current value of the `small_first_last` parameter unchanged. Naturally, this leads to incorrect title-casing
of compound words, containing small words.

For instance, words `end-to-end` and `work-in-progress` are currently
title-cased as `End-To-End` and `Work-In-Progress` instead of the
correct `End-to-End` and `Work-in-Progress`.

items.title: regex package dependency not installed on 0.13 release
items.body: Could the fix for https://github.com/ppannuto/python-titlecase/issues/56 be applied to the 0.13 package?

items.title: It is impossible to prevent titlecase() from reading the ‘~/.titlecase.txt’ file
items.body:
It makes sense to have that behavior as default for the `titlecase`
*command* (especially when it is invoked directly by the user from
the command line), but not for the `titlecase()` *function* that may be
called from some library code, which should not be accessing the file
system at all!

Besides, when writing a script using `titlecase()`, one often needs to
have a way to ensure consistent results across all users’ machines,
regardless of what each particular user has in their `~/.titlecase.txt`
file (and whether they have the file at all). Also, as for libraries,
for some scripts it may not even be appropriate (nor allowed) to
access the user’s file system.

I propose to change the behavior of the `titlecase()` function to, at
the very least, not attempt reading `~/.titlecase.txt` (or any other
files, for that matter) when its `wordlist_file` argument has the
value of `None`. In general, unless an effort is made by the caller,
the call to `titlecase()` should *not* incur any filesystem operations.

I have made the minimal required fix for that in #59.

items.title: setup.py: The ‘regex’ package does not get automatically installed as a dependency
items.body:
If the `regex` package is not installed on the user’s system, the
current `setup.py` file does not install it automatically, causing
the `ModuleNotFoundError` exception in any module importing
`titlecase`:

```
Traceback (most recent call last):
  …
  File "/Users/ib/Library/Python/3.7/lib/python/site-packages/titlecase/__init__.py", line 16, in <module>
    import regex
ModuleNotFoundError: No module named 'regex'
```

This is due to `regex` being [listed in the `setup_requires`
argument in the `setup` call][sr] only, and not being listed
in the `install_requires` one.

[sr]: https://github.com/ppannuto/python-titlecase/blob/cf59b1f2ee85ea4b8926f99928123a1a7eb34526/setup.py#L49

The issue can be resolved by adding the following argument
to the `setup()` call:

	    install_requires=['regex>=2020.4.4'],

We should be aware that this exposes a [known issue with
setuptools][st-issue] when the same package is listed both in
`setup_requires` and `install_requires`. However, this only
applies to the cases when the `setup.py` is invoked manually.

It is my understanding that when the package is installed via
`pip install`, everything works correctly. Given that, I think,
the tradeoff in adding `regex` to `install_requires` is well
justified (especially given that [the setuptools issue][st-issue] will hopefully
be addressed in the future—if not already).

[st-issue]: https://github.com/pypa/setuptools/issues/391

items.title: New release
items.body: Given a few enhancements were made since 0.12.0 it'd be great if they could be released.

items.title: Installation not possible because of missing module regex
items.body:
```
(base) PS C:\XXX\titlecase> python setup.py install --user   
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "setup.py", line 10, in <module>
    from titlecase import __version__
  File "C:\XXX\titlecase\titlecase\__init__.py", line 19, in <module>
    import regex
ModuleNotFoundError: No module named 'regex'
(base) PS C:\XXX\titlecase> 
```

The version should be kept somewhere else or other adjustments in the code are necessary.

items.title: Deprecation warning due to invalid escape sequences in Python 3.7
items.body:
Deprecation warnings are raised due to invalid escape sequences. This can be fixed by using raw strings or escaping the literals.

```
find . -iname '*.py' | grep -v example | xargs -P 4 -I{} python3.8 -Wall -m py_compile {} 
./titlecase/__init__.py:19: DeprecationWarning: invalid escape sequence \.
  SMALL = 'a|an|and|as|at|but|by|en|for|if|in|of|on|or|the|to|v\.?|via|vs\.?'
```

items.title: Callback word is always marked immutable when altered.
items.body: Shouldn't the callback word still follow some of the basic principals of title capitalization?  Such as the first and last words always being capitalized?

items.title: Robot Framework
items.body: The String Libraary for Robot Framework is currently missing titlecase functionality.  Could a How To for calling titlecase from RF possibly be added to the Readme?

items.title: & being changed to &Amp;
items.body: I think you need to be cautious changing any strings that don't start with an alpha. For example while & is valid &Amp; is not. Similarly parts of a title in quotes should be left alone

items.title: All caps words are converted to mixed case
items.body: All caps words, often acronyms, are converted to mixed case, so NASA becomes Nasa. They should remain unchanged, as words with embedded capitals, like GoH, are

items.title: Callback won't convert if words in bracket or quotation
Initial Update
items.body: The initial setup worked, but all your packages are up to date. You can safely close this issue.

items.title: Roman numerals shouldn't be titled
items.body:
E.g.

```
titlecase KING HENRY VIII
King Henry Viii
```
```
titelcase WORLD WAR II
World War Ii
```

Should be rendered as:
King Henry VIII
World War II

items.title: Title is not handling all scenarios
items.body:
If user need to convert some words like aBBCd,TestNG then title case is not handling it properly.

Actual output
title(TestNG)-> Testng
title(aBBCd) -> Abbcd

Expected output
title(TestNG)-> TestNG
title(aBBCd) -> ABBCd

items.title: Capitalisation only working for standard ASCII characters
items.body:
The characters outside of the first 127 bytes in UTF8 cannot be correctly capitalisable.

```
$ titlecase YAE NO
Yae No

$ titlecase ÝÆ ÑØ
ýæ ñø
```

The same applies to lowercase example, the first letters won't be capitalised.

These characters are taken from Latin1 range of Unicode, so characters most likely to have occurred in European languages.  Further testing on 'Latin Extended Additional' characters also shows this issue.

The following diff shows this within the test framework.

```diff
diff --git a/titlecase/tests.py b/titlecase/tests.py
index daee927..05698bd 100644
--- a/titlecase/tests.py
+++ b/titlecase/tests.py
@@ -259,6 +259,22 @@ TEST_DATA = (
     (
         "‘QUOTE’ A GREAT",
         "‘Quote’ a Great",
+    ),
+    (
+        "YEA NO",
+        "Yea No",
+    ),
+    (
+        "ÝÆ ÑØ",
+        "Ýæ Ñø",
+    ),
+    (
+        "yea no",
+        "Yea No",
+    ),
+    (
+        "ýæ ñø",
+        "Ýæ Ñø",
     )
 )
```

items.title: Leading fancy quotes mess with capitalisation
items.body:
If you are using Unicode fancy quotes as leading characters then the first word will not b capitalised correctly.

Capitalisation with first word surrounded by straight quotes, looks fine.

```
>>> titlecase(u"'QUOTE' A GREAT")
u"'Quote' a Great"
```

Capitalisation with first word surrounded by fancy Unicode quotes, first word is not capitalised.

```
>>> titlecase(u"‘QUOTE’ A GREAT")
u'\u2018quote\u2019 a Great'
```

items.title: _mark_immutable does not handle non-ASCII strings
items.body:
Here is a simplified reproduction of an issue I'm seeing while trying to upgrade `titlecase`:
```python
>>> from titlecase import titlecase
>>> titlecase(u'resumé')
u'Resum\xe9'
>>> titlecase(u'resumé', callback=lambda x: x)
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "<stdin>", line 1, in <module>
  File "/Users/lucaswiman/counsyl/website2/vendor/venv/lib/python2.7/site-packages/titlecase/__init__.py", line 72, in titlecase
    new_word = callback(word, all_caps=all_caps)
TypeError: <lambda>() got an unexpected keyword argument 'all_caps'
>>> titlecase(u'resumé', callback=lambda word, **kw: word)
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "<stdin>", line 1, in <module>
  File "/Users/lucaswiman/counsyl/website2/vendor/venv/lib/python2.7/site-packages/titlecase/__init__.py", line 76, in titlecase
    tc_line.append(_mark_immutable(new_word))
  File "/Users/lucaswiman/counsyl/website2/vendor/venv/lib/python2.7/site-packages/titlecase/__init__.py", line 38, in _mark_immutable
    return ImmutableString(text)
UnicodeEncodeError: 'ascii' codec can't encode character u'\xe9' in position 5: ordinal not in range(128)
```

I'll try to submit a pull request for this at some point in the near future.

items.title: Doesn't Handle AT&T Properly
items.body: Even with the callback, always converts it to At&T.

items.title: Small words separated by slash are capitalized
items.body:
Because of the recursive call to `titlecase` in the case where the word is separated by a single slash, small words get capitalized as they are the first word in the string (the only word really).

So:
```
>>> titlecase("a title and/or string")
"A Title And/Or String"
```
instead of 
```
>>> titlecase("a title and/or string")
"A Title and/or String"
```

Could fix this with an optional flag to ignore the rule about starting with a small word that is set in the recursive call only. Or explicitly check for small words again on the split word. I prefer the flag method because this will reapply the callback and any other interesting logic to each word.

items.title: Provide a small cli script to titlecase inputs?
items.body:
Hi,
It could be helpful to add a small script to this project, maybe called `titlecase`, which basically would put its entries to titlecase:
```
$ titlecase "this is the name of an article.pdf"
This Is the Name of an Article.pdf
```

## A small python script?
```python
from sys import argv
from titlecase import titlecase
if __name__ == '__main__':
    for v in argv[1:]:
        print(titlecase(v))
```
Of course, it could be improved with a documentation, command line arguments etc. (I would suggest using [docopt](https://github.com/docopt/docopt)).

## Or a bash alias?
For instance, I just added [this alias](https://bitbucket.org/lbesson/bin/src/master/.bash_aliases#cl-570) to my Bash profile, and it works fine:
```bash
alias titlecase="python -c \"from sys import argv; from titlecase import titlecase; print(titlecase('\n'.join(argv[1:])))\""
```

items.title: Mistakenly captalizes second letter in words that start with a number
items.body: Example: `4th` becomes `4Th` and `1st` becomes `1St`

items.title: Fails on spanish words with accents
items.body:
Hi,

When I try to use the titlecase and provide it with a spanish word like "Señor", because of the letter n and tilde representation, it returns:
SeñOr (just like str.title() )

The only way to fix this behaviour has been to set:

```
titlecase.set_small_word_list('')
```

But this defeats the purpose of the small word list.

Thank you!

items.title: When hyphens are used as colons, e.g. "snakes on a plane - the tv edit - the famous line"
items.body:
The example given results in:

```
Failure
Expected :'Snakes on a Plane - The TV Edit - The Famous Line'
Actual   :'Snakes on a Plane - the Tv Edit - the Famous Line'
```

In a title, when a hyphen has a space on either side of it (" - "), it is basically taking the role of a colon (as commonly seen in filenames). Thus the word following it should be capitalised. Would you agree?

In another note, I noticed that "tv" isn't automatically capitalised to "TV". Perhaps a check could be implemented to capitalise common all-caps acronyms/initialisms such as TV, ATM, IQ, NASA, [etc](http://www.enchantedlearning.com/acronyms/). I understand if that's asking for too much, or if you feel that such a feature would be too far outside the scope of this function's purpose. So on that note, is there a way I could set the uppercase word list myself, similar to the way you can specify your own small word list by calling `set_small_word_list`?

items.title: fix for APOS_SECOND possessive noun (eg: o'brien's)
items.body:
# APOS_SECOND = re.compile(r"^[dol]{1}['â€˜]{1}[a-z]+$", re.I)

APOS_SECOND = re.compile(r"^[dol]{1}['â€˜]{1}[a-z]+(?:['s]{2})?$", re.I)   # fix for possessive noun

items.title: Callback with hyphenated uppercase words
items.body:
Not sure if this is a problem, or just the way I'm using it.

I have strings that are mostly uppercase letters, but with occasional lowercase codes that I want to preserve.  e.g. "DEPARTMENT FOR TRANSPORT (DfT)".

So I created a callback that scanned for lowercase characters (and numbers) in the otherwise uppercase text.  This worked fine, but the problem occurs when there are hyphenated words in the input title. e.g. "RED-BLACK NEWSPAPER TITLE".  This gets passed to the callback as "RED-BLACK", then "red" (lowercase), then "black" (lowercase), and because of my logic checking for lowercase letters, I end up with "red/black Newspaper Title".

Again, I've got a workaround for this so not a big problem, but would there be a way of NOT applying lower() to words when they go through the splitter?

items.title: Titles that are ALMOST all caps
items.body:
This is a good module.  I've run across a problem with titles that are ALMOST all caps -- these don't get converted properly, presumably because we otherwise want to preserve CAPS words in other mixed-case text.   Note the same problem also occurs with accented uppercase letters (these don't get recognised as ALL-CAPS).

e.g.

> > > titlecase( 'a gentleman and a thief' )
> > > 'A Gentleman and a Thief'                                      [good]
> > > titlecase( 'A GENTLEMAN AND A THIEF' )
> > > 'A Gentleman and a Thief'                                      [good]
> > > titlecase( 'A GENTLEMAN AND a THIEF' )
> > > 'A GENTLEMAN AND a THIEF'                              [not so good]
> > > titlecase( 'A GENTLEMAN AND Â THIEF' )
> > > 'A GENTLEMAN AND \xc3\x82 THIEF'                   [not so good]
> > > titlecase( 'A gentleman and a THIEF' )
> > > 'A Gentleman and a THIEF'                                    [possibly good]

Note I've worked round this by converting everything to uppercase and stripping non-ascii first, but would be good to have the module handle it directly, if possible.

items.title: Bug: Punctuation after "Mc"
items.body:
Running titlecase on `oblon, spivak, mcclelland, maier & neustadt` yields `Oblon, Spivak, McClelland Maier & Neustadt`. Notice that the comma was removed after the McClelland.  

This can be fixed by modifying the regex for catching Mc words:

```
MAC_MC = re.compile(r"^([Mm]c)(\w.+)")
```

Notice that the second regex group is now `\w.+` rather than `\w+`

items.title: Hyphens and Slashes Should be Handled Recursively
items.body:
If you try running titlecase on the following: `o'melveny/o'doyle` only the first name in the apostrophe is handled properly, the second one is not, and you end up with the following: `O'Melveny/O'doyle`.  This can be fixed by making recursive calls on each word after splitting up the slash.

Below I suggest a replacement for the bottom half of the inner loop of titlecase:

```
        if "/" in word and "//" not in word:
            slashed = map(lambda t: titlecase(t,callback), word.split('/'))
            tc_line.append("/".join(slashed))
            continue

        if '-' in word:
            hyphenated = map(lambda t: titlecase(t,callback), word.split('-'))
            tc_line.append("-".join(hyphenated))
            continue

        # Just a normal word that needs to be capitalized
        tc_line.append(CAPFIRST.sub(lambda m: m.group(0).upper(), word))
```

items.title: Bug with Apostrophes
items.body:
If you try titlecase on `l'grange`, you get the following as output: `L'GranGe`. Notice the second `G` is capitalized.

The problem is because we use replace instead of string concatenation in the following code:

```
            if APOS_SECOND.match(word):
                word = word.replace(word[0], word[0].upper())
                word = word.replace(word[2], word[2].upper())
                tc_line.append(word)
                continue
```

Which should be replaced with:

```
            if APOS_SECOND.match(word):
                word = word[0].upper() + word[1] + word[2].upper() + word[3:]
                tc_line.append(word)
                continue
```

items.title: Problem with apostrophes in word
items.body:
Hello!
I am having difficulties with using the library for words containing apostrophes in this form. Your library does not translate these words. For example, the phrase "COYOTE&#x2019:S COUSIN" was left without changes. 
Can you please solve this problem?

Thanks.

items.title: Fails to properly parse all caps words when a string contains a number
items.body:
titlecase("FOO BAR 5TH ST") = "FOO BAR 5TH ST"

I'd expect "Foo Bar 5th St"

items.title: Excessive MAC_MC regexp behaviour
items.body:
In [1]: from titlecase import titlecase

In [2]: titlecase('machine')
Out[2]: 'MacHine'

I suppose the best solution is to remove letter 'a' from regexp:
MAC_MC = re.compile(r"^([Mm]c)(\w+)")
